Award.AwardTitle: ChANgE Chem: Transforming Chemistry with Cognitive Apprenticeship for Engineers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Transforming Chemistry with Cognitive AppreNticeship for Engineers (ChANge Chem) project is working to improve the quality of undergraduate STEM education by transforming the general chemistry curriculum for engineering students to a more contextually relevant and engaging experience. The ChANge Chem endeavor employs the use of cognitive apprenticeship strategies, an educational framework steeped in our understanding of how students learn, to develop a sequence of activities that emulate and make explicit the way engineers think, comprehend, and work. The transformed curriculum situates water, air, waste and energy as fundamental organizing principles in practical engineering problems, communicated as human interest stories. Project goals are organized around the three overarching themes of the Design, Develop and Test components of the research and development cycle.

Intellectual Merit
ChANgE Chem advances our understanding of how people learn chemistry and develop the skills for addressing engineering design problems. The project applies a unique approach to create new learning materials and teaching strategies, develop faculty expertise, implement an educational innovation and assess student achievement. Collectively, the project leadership has extensive experience with instructional materials development, innovative pedagogical practices and the use of technology as a learning tool. Individually, the team possesses expertise in chemistry, environmental engineering, chemical engineering, chemical education and STEM education.

Broader Impacts
ChANgE Chem broadens participation in STEM by designing for the recruitment and retention of women and individuals from diverse cultural, racial and ethnic backgrounds. Producing a transferable model of chemistry education for engineers and communicating results through established networks affords the potential of widespread adoption by a variety of institutions. By contributing a more diverse and better-qualified engineering workforce, ChANge Chem serves society by facilitating sustained economic growth, national security and an informed electorate.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the ChANgE Chem project (Transforming Chemistry with Cognitive AppreNticeship for Engineers) was to build a set of learning materials for undergraduate chemistry based upon how engineers use chemistry in their professional work. We took this approach as a way of motivating students, especially women and students from ethnic minorities, to find chemistry more useful and to stay involved in studying engineering.

We created a series of 6 projects wherein students use their understanding of chemistry to explore solutions to complex engineering problems that matter to people who live in their communities, like using alternative fuels for energy generation. In each of these projects, students also consider the social, economic, and environmental implications of their solutions as well as the related chemistry and engineering concepts. Working in teams, students complete these projects during the discussion or recitation part of the course.

Over three years, ChANgE Chem directly impacted more than 600 students at the University of Florida. When students learn using these projects, they better understand themselves as learners and gain confidence in their professional and interpersonal skills as well as their mathematics and science abilities. As one student indicated, "I don’t have any experience, but I felt like it was something that someone would really ask for in the professional world." and another stated "Completing them and presenting our work at the end made me feel like I had accomplished something by the end of the course. Additionally, I feel like I belong as an engineer."

While completing the projects, students were engaged, attending class and working together. They reported that the work gave them a purpose—"This is something I actually want to be doing." These are all important outcomes for helping students to see themselves as future engineers, to see value in schoolwork as it relates to their future career and thus improving their motivation for continuing to study engineering. As a project team, we find these results promising and if implemented in other institutions the model may benefit even more students.

A diverse team of faculty and graduate students from the colleges of education, science, and engineering worked together on this project. The team enjoyed working together, gained new perspectives about people and practices outside of their own fields, learned to communicate within the group and built new relationships during the collaboration. For the graduate students who worked on the project, their participation helped them to see that the basic knowledge they study in their research labs has real-world applications. One of them indicated, "It’s very nice to collaborate with new people. I think sometimes we get stuck in such a rut with our research groups, and we’re always talking about the same thing. It’s like a breath of fresh air almost to collaborate with new people and learn some new things and definitely applications to industry, looking at very specific processes and how the chemistry fits into certain things in industry is, I think, really cool.” For the faculty members, this project also taught them about new teaching strategies, which they then used in their classrooms. “For example, sometimes I used a flow diagram in my teaching before, but not really in a consistent way; and now I realize, ‘oh this is a very powerful tool I can use,’ and I started to use it more.”

Several chemistry instructors have inquired about using the materials created by the ChANgE Chem Project. These materials are now available to any interested users, and will continue to be used at the University of Florida after the project is completed.
